noteValue: Art from the Nordic countries

The art museum in Tønder exhibits art from the Nordic countries from 1880 to the present. Furthermore, the museum features special exhibitions of artwork from the rich tradition of Scandinavian design. All of the exhibitions are presented in large, bright, and appealing rooms decorated in the Nordic style. The building was erected in 1999.

name.label: Gefängnismuseum Hamburg · in der Justizvollzugsanstalt Glasmoor
Mikkelberg - Nordisk center for kunst og cricket
St Peter-Ording National Park Centre, Wadden Sea Conservation Station

noteValue: Biodiversity amidst sand, wind and tides

In this exhibition, visitors can learn about the natural forces of the North Sea – water, wind and sand – and how they have shaped the Wadden Sea. Particular emphasis is given to the birdlife and history of St Peter-Ording. Aquariums and the National Park cinema invite visitors to marvel at the inhabitants of the Wadden Sea World Heritage Site.

name.label: Pellworm National Park Centre, Wadden Sea Conservation Station

noteValue: Experience nature in the heart of the Wadden Sea

At the Pellworm conservation centre, visitors can study life in the Wadden Sea and the North Sea at first hand. Under the magnifying glass, the fascinating shapes of soft corals and bird feathers are revealed. In the aquariums, fish, crabs and snails invite visitors to take a closer look. The centre offers a chance to learn all about the natural world of Pellworm and nearby islands.

name.label: National park house Hooge, conservation center wadden sea

noteValue: Discover the Halligen islands and Wadden Sea

The Hooge National Park Centre has a varied exhibition on the Halligen biosphere and the Wadden Sea World Heritage Site, with a particular focus on life on a Halligen island over time. The Halligen islands are unique to this region and form part of a constantly changing landscape, which visitors can learn all about at the centre.

openingTimes.description: Die Schauhöhle ist nur in den Sommermonaten geöffnet.

noteValue: Exhibition on Fehmarn’s natural history

In the town hall is a geology exhibition organised by Fehmarn Environmental Council (entrance at the rear of the building). Themes and exhibits include the geology of northern Germany, the island of Fehmarn’s development from the Palaeozoic to modern times, how amber is formed, Fehmarn during the Ice Age, Fehmarn’s coastline and drill samples from the Fehmarn Belt.
Submarine tour and museum

Peer through a genuine periscope, or try out one of the cramped crew berths: visitors to the legendary U11 in the Port of Burgstaaken can experience at first hand what life was like on board. For technophiles, there’s a chance to see original torpedo tubes and the engine room. In the adjacent museum, visitors can learn about the German submarine fleet in the post-war period.
Independent theatre in Flensburg

Theaterwerkstatt Pilkentafel is a permanent venue and rehearsal space for contemporary dance and performing arts in Flensburg. It is well connected, internationally renowned and involved in a number of associations. In 2019, it was awarded the Theaterpreis des Bundes, a national theatre prize.
Park and seal centre in St Peter-Ording

Enjoy an experience-packed day in the great outdoors at Westküstenpark and its internationally award-winning seal centre. Aside from the seals, the beautiful 14.5-hectare park is home to more than 800 other wild and domestic animals, including several endangered species. The  park  directly borders the Wadden Sea National Park and is a certified sustainability education centre.
New life in old buildings

At the heart of Eckernförde’s old town are the former premises of Fischräucherei Hopp, a fish smokery that closed in 1962 after 42 years in business. All the buildings were granted protected heritage status in 2004. Since 2012, the association Alte Fischräucherei Eckernförde has been developing the former Hopp premises into a discovery centre where visitors can learn about the history of fishing and the fishing industry in Eckernförde.
World War 2 memorial

The Frøslev Camp is one of Europe’s most well preserved internment camps. The permanent exhibitions are to be found in the main watchtower and in the former prisoners hut H4. The exhibitions shows the most important aspects of the camp history in the period 1944-45. In the main watchtower the political background, establishment, the building history etc. and the Danish Administration is in focus.
Protecting biodiversity

The exhibition ‘Birdlife between river and sea’ documents the fascinating nature and eventful history of the Priwall Peninsula and its importance for avian populations. Multimedia and interactive stations allow visitors to immerse themselves in the birdlife of the Priwall and surrounding region.

Brundlund Castle & Art Museum has an impressive collection of works by Southern Jutland artists from the late 1700s to the present day. The artworks continue outside where a stunning collection of sculptures is exhibited in the idyllic castle park.
Industrial heritage

Cathrinesminde Brickworks is a well-preserved cultural environment and museum, designated as one of Denmark’s most important monuments to its industrial heritage.
The museum tells the story of the brick industry, which flourished around Flensburg Fjord for more than 200 years.
Tønder Lace
Cap Arcona memorial site

When the Neuengamme concentration camp was evacuated in April 1945, the SS deported more than 9,000 prisoners to Lübeck, where they were then crammed onto the Cap Arcona and Thielbek. On the afternoon of 3 May, the two ships were bombed in the bay of Neustadt. The Cap Arcona Museum, located in an annex to the city museum zeiTTor, has a permanent exhibition on the events.
Around 130 gravestones and documentation

A small permanent exhibition recently opened in the cemetery hall. It documents the history of Elmshorn’s Jewish citizens and their persecution by the National Socialists. The over 300-year-old Jewish cemetery, with over 150 preserved gravestones and the cemetery hall, is the last surviving trace of Elmshorn’s former Jewish community in the town.
Tropical house and park

This fascinating tropical house, set amidst a large park, transports visitors to an exotic world of butterflies and plants. The 450-square-metre building is kept at a temperature of 26 degrees. Visitors can see 40 different butterfly species from Asia, Africa and America and witness their fascinating metamorphoses. The park is a perfect place for walks, games and other outdoor activities.

resource.title: Garten der Schmetterlinge_innen
resource.description: Garten der Schmetterlinge im tropischen Haus

resource.title: Garten der Schmetterlinge_Falter
resource.description: Garten der Schmetterlinge Falter in Terrarium

noteValue: history and workings of the mill

Højer Mill is both a museum and a well-preserved cultural-historical environment where milling and grain trading took place from 1857 to 1972. Find out about the history and workings of the mill and learn about life in Tønder Marsh in the exhibitions in the two grain stores.Rambling trails and paths from Højer Mill lead you to scenic nature experiences.
Small exhibition about the Wadden Sea

In the house to the left of the lighthouse is a small exhibition about the Wadden Sea National Park. Visitors can observe the diverse flora and fauna of the North Sea (including crabs and anthozoans) in the aquarium and examine mussels, sea moss and feathers in minute detail under the microscope. There are also lots of fascinating facts about the Westerheversand lighthouse.
Exhibition in Beltringharder Koog

Beltringharder Koog has a fascinating history. What once were mudflats are now home to Schleswig-Holstein's largest nature reserve, with a saltwater lagoon for migratory birds, pastures for rare meadow birds and a virgin forest growing in the wilderness zone. The exhibition offers many fascinating insights into the natural world of the Beltringharder Koog and the adjoining areas of the Wadden Sea National Park.
Nature conservation and the Wadden Sea

A 90 m² exhibition area covering the topics of national parks around the world, the ecology of the Wadden Sea, coastal conservation and how the landscapes and cultures of the marsh islands of Nordstrand and Pellworm and the Halligen island of Südfall have developed over time. Two marine aquariums offer a glimpse into the underwater world. The centre offers Wadden Sea excursions, birdwatching tours and activity days.
Explore Amrum’s natural world

The wide Kniepsand sandbank, dunes full of life, seagrass meadows, mussel beds – Amrum and the surrounding sea and mudflats make up a unique natural world. In this exhibition with several aquariums, visitors can learn many interesting things about the island’s flora and fauna. They can also try their hand at ‘boßeln’ – a game similar to bowls – on an outdoor course amidst the dunes.
Exhibition | Memorial

The main exhibition “Traces of History: Neuengamme Concentration Camp 1938–1945 and Its Post-War History” focuses on the history of Neuengamme concentration camp and its satellite camps from 1938 to 1945. First and foremost, it documents the crimes committed at this site against the prisoners who were transported here from many different countries. It portrays the process of de-humanisation, everyday life and the survival strategies of prisoners in Neuengamme and its satellite camps.
Explore the Marks of history

At Mark, you experience concrete stories about Billund Municipality's development, which is exemplary of the development of all of Denmark: from an agricultural society to an industrial society to a society that increasingly makes a living on tourism.

‚Dat ole Hus’ (The Old House) is a small half-timbered cottage, which was built in 1804. It is the centre of a small local history museum, which was established by the Hauschildt couple in 1961. Within guided tours the interiors can be visited. They offer a vivid impression of rural life in the region from the 18th to the 20th century. The farm tools, which are exhibited in a stable, a carriage shed and a beehive, originate from the same period.
The museum is well-known for offering coffee and waffles with a local speciality: red fruit jelly. The visitor can enjoy this speciality either in the cosy, stove-heated sitting room in wintertime or in the garden in summertime.Regularly the museum shows small temporary exhibitions on various subjects.
Museum restaurant offering traditional waffles during the opening hours of the museum
Motorway A 7 exit ‚Neumünster Mitte’
Federal road B 430, exit ‚Aukrug-Bünzen’

from the direction of Nortorf: exit ‚Aukrug-Böken’, Bünzerstraße

Half-timbered cottage

The cottage was built in 1804 and is now the centre of a small museum of local history and culture. Guided tours through the rooms give visitors a vivid impression of how local farmers lived between the 18th and the early 20th century. Tools from the same period are on display in the stable building, shed, and an apiary.

Geological finds of the “Liether Kalkgrube” (Lieth lime pit) nearby as well as objects from the pre- and early history are presented. They belong to the collections of the Industriemuseum Elmshorn. The building is also used by two local history associations:
- Elmshorner Heimatverein "Tru un fast", chairman Jürgen Kröger (local history association)
- Vereinigung für Familienkunde, chairman Karl-Heinz Kuhlemann (genealogy association)
For information on the exhibition and the local history collection please contact the Industriemuseum Elmshorn
Sun 11 am – 12 pm, Wed 2-5 pm, closed throughout school holidays
Free

The "Kieler Antikensammlung" (Kiel collection of classical art) was established on the initiative of Peter Wilhelm Forchhammer (1801-1894). He lectured as a professor of ancient history at the Christian-Albrechts-Universität in Kiel. The museum was opened on January 18th in 1843. The collection is unique in Northern Germany.
The museum owns an extensive collection of original classical works (Greek pottery vessels and small classical objects of art). Additionally, it has a large collection of cast copies of important Greek and Roman sculptures (e.g. sculptures of the Parthenon, the Apollo of Belvedere, Laocoon).Original vases and small classical objects of art give a vivid impression of antiquity. The vases are fascinating because of the great variety of their forms and their lively depictions. The latter tell of the gods and heroes of the Greeks and of their banquets and their ideas of the world beyond death.The "Kieler Antikensammlung" combines small original objects of art with large copied sculptures. Thus it gives the visitors an insight into the art and cultural history of the antiquity from the 2nd millennium BC to the times of the Roman Empire.
On sale in the museum: post cards, publications, information leaflets
on the premises: Café "Zum blauen Kameel"
Parking facilities in the underground car park at the castle (Dänische Str.) or in the car park on Jensendamm

(registered association of the friends of the classical art collection) (Postfach 4120, 24100 Kiel, phone: +49 (0)4 31 - 5 33 55 53; Fax: +49 (0)4 31 - 5 33 55 90). They regularly organize lectures and other events at the "Antikensammlung".
Free

One of the most important attractions on the island of Sylt originates from Neolithic times: It is the megalithic tomb “Denghoog” close to Wenningstedt. The meaning of the name is „thing hill“, which is an assembly place. The mound was established as a clan or family tomb in the third millennium before Christ. In the large earthen mound there is a completely preserved polygonal stone chamber roofed with six mighty lintels. The passage and the burial chamber can be visited through a very narrow artificial entrance and over a steep ladder.

Apr.-Oct. Mon-Fri 10 am - 4 pm, Sat, Sun and Holyday 11 am - 4 pm
closed Nov.-March

Adults 2,50 €, without culture card 4,50 €

Combination card for all museums on Sylt (1 adult and 2 children) 12,50 €
Explore a burial mound

The Denghoog is one of the most impressive and best-preserved megalithic tombs in northern Europe. It is as old as Stonehenge in England. The roof and boundary stones weigh up to 18,000 kg each. The chamber is accessible either through a six-metre-long corridor or an opening in the roof.

Weber’s drawing „Das Verhängnis“ (Fate) from 1931, which appeared in the brochure „Hitler – ein deutsches Verhängnis“ (Hitler – a German Fate) by E. Niekisch, is world-famous. It expresses his foresight of the threatening catastrophe of the Second World War. But there are about 300 other drawings, woodcuts, oil paintings and especially lithographs by the satirical graphic artist A. Paul Weber to be discovered.
The funny animal pictures, the book illustrations on e.g. “Reineke Fuchs” (Reynard the Fox), the cheerful and vicious sheets on art and the art scene, the chess games between historical characters, the “Eulenspiegel” motifs, the critical works by which Weber denounces social and political defects and condemns war and violence, a cycle of prisoner pictures and the vividly warning drawings on the destruction of our environment are well worth a visit. In addition, a lithographer’s workshop that is still able to operate can be visited.
sufficient parking facilities in front of the house
from Lübeck: by the federal road B 207
from Hamburg: by the motorway A 1 in the direction of Berlin (exit Ratzeburg), then by the federal road B 207
Video films on A. Paul Weber and the production of lithographs can be shown on demand

The "Weber-Museum" is beautifully located on an island in the "Ratzeburger See" (Ratzeburg Lake). Passenger ships run on the lake, the landing stage is just a few metres away. Next to the museum is the "Kreismuseum Herzogtum Lauenburg" with its extensive collections. It is housed in the summer residence of the Mecklenburg dukes (built in 1766). Right next to it stands the medieval cathedral of "Heinrich der Löwe".
The "Weber-Museum" is supported by the "A. Paul Weber-Gesellschaft" (A. Paul Weber Association).
Critical and satirical graphic art

The works of the satirical artist A. Paul Weber consist of book illustrations, humorous and biting treatises on art and the art scene, chess matches between historical figures, Eugenspiegel motifs, his critical commentaries on society and politics, and haunting drawings warning of the destruction of the environment. A fully functional lithographic print workshop is also on display.

The 'Elektro-Museum Rendsburg der Schleswig-Holstein Netz AG' (Schleswig-Holstein Netz joint-stock company museum on electricity) conveys an overview on the history of electrification. In addition to technical changes, the scientific-technical processes and results the museum also shows the social effects. Different furnished rooms like a living room, a music room, a child’s room, a laundry and a study, which are fitted with numerous lovingly restored exhibits from the times of Art Noveau, illustrate the technical level of that time.In the extensive presentation on the electrification of house and home visitors can find some rarities like the darning mushroom that is illuminated from the inside and that Konrad Adenauer had patented or the 'Orchestrion' from 1908, which replaces a complete orchestra.
Please follow the signs 'Elektro-Museum'.
The museum is situated in the middle of the town, 5 minutes from the railway station.
Parking facilities available (finance office car park)
Guided group tours by appointment

History of electricity

Travel back in time through the history of electricity: The museum presents the social impact as well as technical changes. Numerous rooms – a living room, music room, playroom, laundry, and den – furnished with countless exhibits from the Jugendstil period document the technological development of the period.

openingTimes.description: Wer bereits auf dem Gelände ist, kann bis 19:00 Uhr bleiben.

noteValue:
The „Prinzenpalais“, which was built around 1700, is the only preserved three-winged manor-house within the town. Many important personalities owned it. It was named “Prinzenpalais” (prince’s palace) after Friedrich Emil August Prince of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Noer. Today it houses the regional archive that keeps more than 12.000 parchment documents, 90.000 maps, almost 43.000 metres of records on its shelves and nearly 150.000 photographs. The manifold sources cover the Middle Ages up to the present and extend onto all fields like regional, cultural, economic, social, technical and contemporary history. The reference library on regional history contains more than 150.000 volumes. 
As a special institution for the preservation of audiovisual sources the regional archive is at the same time the regional film archive of Schleswig-Holstein. All film records of the Land are kept, restored and collected here.The archive also has rooms for changing exhibition on historical topics.
Reading room: mon, tue, thu 8.30 am – 5 pm, wed 8.30-6:30 pm
Free entrance
The mill has a water wheel of almost 5 metres in diameter and two pairs of millstones. It originates from 1842 and is one of the few water mills that are still in working order today.
open daily round the clock
The mill has a water wheel of almost 5 metres in diameter and two pairs of millstones. It originates from 1842 and is one of the few water mills that are still in working order today.

In the nature conservation centre Bergenhusen the main emphasis is put on the white stork and its habitat. Every year thousands of visitors, among them many children, adolescents and school classes, come to the village in Stapelholm during the six month of the stork season. They take part in guided tours and have the possibility to learn about the stork, its endangerment and its protection in the exhibition of the centre. In this museum other animal and plant species, which need a similar biosphere like the stork, are also taken into consideration.
Museum shop
Gaststätte Hoier Boier, Dörpstroot 12 A (Inn)
Landgasthof Dehn, Dörpstroot 30 (Inn)

Coming from Hamburg on the motorway A 7 exit ‘Rendsburger Kreuz” in the direction of Rendsburg. Follow the signs leading to St. Peter-Ording. Take the federal road B 202 through Hohn and Erfde until you reach Norderstapel. In Norderstapel turn off to the right in the direction of Kropp. After approx. 3 kms turn off to the right to Bergenhusen. In Bergenhusen follow the signs to the nature conservation centre.

‚A look into the stork’s nest’ with a live-transmission on the large screen of the nature conservation centre by a remote controlled video camera. So the hatching of the nestlings, the feeding and other details from the daily life of a stork’s family can be seen very closely without disturbing the birds.
Guided tours of the storks’ village and the exhibition.

Crafts and trades from various eras

Located in the straw and feed store of a former cowshed, this museum exhibits a large collection of restored equipment and machinery used for forestry, agriculture, housekeeping and myriad crafts and trades from different eras. Some of the items are still functional and can be used under supervision.
Theatre | Readings

Each season, the theatre’s programme includes five in-house productions in Low German, ranging from comedies to drama. It also includes a children’s play in standard German just before Christmas and numerous special events such as readings, concerts, and cabaret – usually in Low German but sometimes in standard German.
Enjoy Low German!

The stages of the Low German Theatre in Kiel are housed in the Theater am Wilhelmplatz. In April 2021, the theatre will be celebrating its 100th anniversary. Each season, we present six plays in Low German: Comedies, classic drama, contemporary plays and readings, and a Christmas fairy-tale in standard German.
Low German theatre since 1934

The Low German Theatre in Rendsburg was founded in 1934 by a large group of theatre enthusiasts. Each year, the theatre group rehearses three plays in Low German, which they present in the Rendsburg City Theatre and around the region.
Memorial park

The “Hamburger Friedhof” (Hamburg cemetary) memorial park in the municipality of Kropp is a place to linger and reflect. The focus of the memorial is on euthanasia in Kropp. In 2019, it was declared a “cultural monument with particular value for historica
May-Sept. Thu-Sun 2-6pm
free admission
100-years of music technology

The music industry from 1880 to 1980. The 400-sqm museum features music players, musical clocks, phonographs, gramophones, radios – from crystal radios and Volksempfänger to radiograms, car and portable radios, Tefifons, jukeboxes, tape recorders, and wire recorders. Visitors will receive interactive explanations and demonstrations from long-gone eras.

Phonomuseum 'Alte Schule', Blick in Ausstellung Radios

noteValue: The governor’s house of the ‘Flachsröste’ (building where flax used to be steeped) is the only remaining building of a former concentration camp in Schleswig-Holstein. In a first exhibition a death march from Auschwitz to Holstein in 1945 is documented. This march stands for the fate of hundreds of prisoners from different national socialist concentration camps, who were rushed through the German Reich in the last month of the Second World War.

at any time by appointment

Your Donation is welcome
Commemoration | Documentation*

The Ahrensbök Memorial was opened on 8 May 2001 in the only surviving building in Schleswig-Holstein that housed a former concentration camp in 1933. The beginnings, everyday life, and end of the Nazi dictatorship from 1933 to 1945 are examined using examples from the region. The memorial is a place of documentation, exhibition, reflection, education, and encounters in one.

The castle of Ahrensburg with its four prominent corner towers and the mout was built around 1585 as a triple house in Renaissance style by order of Count Peter Rantzau. Until 1759 the Rantzau family lived here. Then, the Danish treasurer and later liege lord Heinrich Carl Schimmelmann bought the castle. He had some structural changes made which complied with the tastes of Rococo and Early Classicism.
The Schimmelmann family lived in the castle until 1932. Since 1955 it is open to the public.
Today Ahrensburg Castle is a unique testimony of noble culture in Schleswig-Holstein. It shows luxurious interiors with valuable panellings, parquet floors, stuccoed ceilings, exquisite furniture, paintings and Meissen china.

birthday celebrations in the vaulted cellar: The vaulted cellar from the 16th century can be rented for festivities. The unique charm of the venerable premises will create a special atmosphere for every kind of event.

Since December 2002: Ahrensburg Castle Foundation
The foundation has the purpose to preserve, to run, to maintain and to appropriately extend the listed castle of Ahrensburg with its fittings, land and historical ambience as a museum and cultural monument of national importance.
Additionally, the foundation aims at broadening knowledge on the castle by research, documentation and publication. The castle and its premises are open to the public as a museum as well as for cultural events.

Adults 7,- €, reduced charge 4,50,- €,
Children 4-14 years 3,50 €; family ticket 16,- €
Aristocratic culture

Ahrensburg Castle was commissioned by Count Peter Rantzau in 1585 to be built in the Renaissance style as a triple house with four distinctive corner towers and a moat. Today, the castle’s splendid interior is a unique example of aristocratic culture in Schleswig-Holstein with precious wainscoting, parquet flooring, stucco ceilings, exquisite furniture, paintings, and Meissen porcelain.

The windmill rises impressively over the town of Kappeln. Measuring 30 metres it is the highest in the region. The Tourist Information and the registry office are located in it. In addition, there is an exhibition on the function and use of this important technical monument. At the place of a burnt-down predecessor, the tower mill that is built in Dutch style and with a gallery was erected in 1888. In addition to its mighty square foundations it is built solidly of stones in the area of the octagonal shingled upper part and the cap, too. It shows technical innovations of its time: it was driven either by wind or by a steam engine. A rarity is the double use as a flour mill and a sawmill.

June to Sept. Mon-Fri 10 am-5 pm, Sat + Sun 10 am-2 pm.
April/May and Oct. Mon-Fri 10 am-5 pm, Sat 10 am-2 pm, Sun as required in the holidays.
Nov. to March Mon + Fri 10am-4 pm.
Monument | Technical documentation

At 30 metres, the highest windmill of the state towers above the town of Kappeln. Inside, the mill houses technical documentation on how this important monument worked and was used. Built in 1888 to replace its predecessor, which had been destroyed by a fire, this smock mill has brick walls that extend up beyond the four-sided base to the shingled octagon upper framework and into the cap.

resource.title: Windmühle Amanda

noteValue: The windmill in the village of Nebel on Amrum island is one of the few “companions of the wind” from the North Frisian historical times. It was built on the highest geest ridge of the island in 1771. In the first years pearl barley were husked in the so-called “Erdholländer” windmill (kind of tower mill that is built in Dutch style). In 1922 the windmill got a cellar. The corn was kept in the adjoined shed. The grinding stopped in 1963. On the initiative of the island’s pastor Pörksen, an association kept the mill and changed the building into a local history museum. The history of the building, the flora and fauna of the island and the sea, archaeological finds as well as traditional items are presented in the mill today.
History of the mill and the island

The windmill is located in Nebel, on Amrum, and is one of the few still functioning historical windmills in North Friesland. Built in 1771 on the highest Geest of the island, the windmill now features exhibits on the history of the house, the flora and fauna of the island and the sea, as well as prehistoric and cultural artefacts.

Sandy habitat

An adventuresome walk through the natural sandy habitats on Amrum. Both inside the nature centre and outside – sand is everywhere. At different stations, five aquariums provide insights into the underwater world on Amrum’s coasts by demonstrating how plants and birds deal with sand.

In the town museum in the "Alte Münze", one of the oldest and most beautiful buildings in Friedrichstadt, you can learn exciting facts about the history of the Dutch town. 
The founding of the town, religious diversity and everyday life in different eras are presented in the modern exhibition on three levels.
You can also take a look inside the Mennonite Church, the place of worship of Friedrichstadt's smallest religious community.

On sale in the museum: postcards, books, tiles, museum socks.
There are several opportunities for having tea throughout the town.
Restaurants serve almost everything from fish in a bun to a three-course menu.

The museum is located in the city center, just a few steps away from the historic market square. The route is signposted.

Friedrichstadt has a parking guidance system and the old town is within walking distance of all parking lots and the train station.

By car from Hamburg: motorway A7, Rendsburger Kreuz (crossing) motorway BAB 210, then federal road B 202 in the direction of St. Peter Ording or the motorway A 23, from Heide use the federal roads B5 and B 202 to Friedrichstadt
By railway from Hamburg: route Hamburg-Westerland; from Kiel: Kiel-Husum, Husum-Hamburg
Parking facilities can be found in the streets or on the marketplace.
Guided tours can be booked by calling 04881/1511

Various themed city tours are available at the museum.
Publications on the history of the town.

Apr., May and Oct.: Tue-Sun 12 am - 4 pm
Jun-Sept.: Tue-Sun 11 am - 5 pm
Tour of the scenic townscape of Friedrichstadt on foot or by boat on a canal trip
In Friedrichstadt much of the original townscape is still intact. Houses with craw step gables, waterways in the midst of town and an orthogonal road network create the impression of a Dutch town

Admission: 3,50 Euro
Reduced 3.00 Euro (groups, students, people with disabilities)
School classes 25,- Euro
Urban history | Religious communities

The museum is located in an old warehouse built in 1626 by the Duke’s governor. The people of Friedrichtsstadt believed they would be granted the right to mint coins, so they named the house “Münze” (coin). The museum focuses on the founding of the town, the religious communities who lived in Friedrichstadt, and everyday life.

The railway track from Süderbrarup through Scheggerott to Kappeln, which is 13 kilometres long, was built in 1904. After almost 70 years the passenger services were stopped, later the freight traffic as well. Since 1979 the northernmost museum train of Germany is in operation here. On about 10-15 days mainly during the summer season historical trains with steam locomotives run through the idyllic landscape of Angeln. Longer trips, for instance to Flensburg or Denmark, are also on the schedule. There are also offers for people who are not so enthusiastic about trains, for instance the "Kunstschienen" (art tracks) organized by the "Kappelner Kunst- und Kulturverein" (Kappeln art and culture association).
Please call for operating days
Adults 10,- €, families 18,- €, children 4,- €
Heritage railway | Rides

The 13-kilometre railway from Süderbrarup to Kappeln via Scheggerott was built in 1904. After almost 70 years, passenger and later cargo transport were discontinued. Since 1979, Germany’s northernmost heritage railway has been operating here. In the summer, steam engines take historical trains through the idyllic landscape of Angeln and sometimes to Flensburg or Denmark.

The village of Unewatt is situated at the edge of the charming Langballig pasture valley close to Langballig. It constitutes the country-side museum of the Angeln region. Its “museum islands” stretch over the historical centre of the village. At the entrance to the village the Marxenhaus is located, which was moved here from Süderbrarup. In the middle of the village the butter mill, which is a part of a former diary, was reconstructed. Its heart is the rotating butter churn, which is driven by a water-wheel.
The corn windmill “Fortuna” is located above the village, where it can be seen over a long distance. It is a windmill built in Dutch style with a gallery from 1878. Large technical farming implements as well as a collection of farming vehicles expect the visitor in the Christesen barn at the edge of the village.

April Fri-Sun 10 am – 5 pm
May-Sept. Tue-Sun 10 am – 5 pm
Oct. Fri-Sun 10 am – 5 pm
Nov.-March closed
groups and guided tours by appointment

Village with museum islands

The Anglian Countryside Museum in Unewatt addresses everyday life in the countryside and how it changed over the years. Nestled amongst gently rolling hills, interspersed with bends and smaller rivers, the museum comprises an entire village with a total of five museum islands and one large exhibition hall featuring regularly changing exhibitions on the cultural history and folklore of the region.

name.label: Anna Mill Museum of Local History and Culture

noteValue: The restored windmill is an „Erd- und Kellerholländer“ (kind of tower mill built in Dutch style which has a stage, a large room at the bottom of the mill) from 1904/05. Farming, craft and household tools as well as records from the village history are exhibited.
may-sept. every 1st Sun of a month 10 am – 12 pm and by appointment
Adults 1,50 €, children/pupils 0,50 €, groups 1,- € per person (with guided tour)
Local history | Museum forge*

The Anna mill, built in 1904, is located on the edge of town. Inside and outside, it features exhibits from domestic life, agriculture, and the construction of wooden ships. The museum smithy contains a functional smithy that offers blacksmith demonstrations on special occasions.

The „Archäologische Landesmuseum“ (regional archaeological museum) within the „Stiftung Schleswig-Holsteinische Landesmuseen Schloß Gottorf“ presents the archaeology of the region starting with the Stone Age hunters up to the citizens of medieval towns. The exhibition “reindeer hunters – reindeer herders” deals with the reindeer hunters of the post ice age and the life of the reindeer herding Sami in Northern Europe. The famous bog bodies are the central exhibits in the newly opened special exhibition “Iron Age Man”. The exhibition “village – castle – church – town – Schleswig – Holstein in the Middle Ages” illustrates the life of people in rural areas in towns on the basis of archaeological research.
The bog find of Nydam with the Nydam boat, which is of international importance, is the highlight of the newly designed exhibition in the Nydam hall.The presentation “Ebba Dettenberg-Weddig collection – Ethiopia on the edge of revolution” and the workshop exhibition “on the samurai’s world” show objects from the ethnological collections of the “Christian-Albrechts-Universität” (Kiel University). In addition to the permanent exhibitions there are also special exhibitions on show.
Publications on the archaeology of the Land Schleswig-Holstein as well as replicas on sale
Catering facilities existing on the „Schloßinsel” (castle island)
80,000 years of human history

The Archaeological Museum in Gottorf Castle is located on the Schleswig museum island in the heart of Schleswig-Holstein. It contains more than 10 million artefacts from 80,000 years of human history, many of which were discovered in Germany’s northernmost state. The museum presents selected exhibits, including the spectacular Nydam boat and bog bodies.

noteValue:
The “Tierpark Warder” (Warder zoo) is an exceptional zoo. There are no lions or elephants but domestic animals that are as rare as the Siberian tiger and therefore not known to many people. 1.400 mostly European domestic and farm productive animals of 160 species can be watched along the 3 km-trail-system through the zoo. Mangalitza pigs, giant donkeys, Belgian “Bartkaninchen” (rare rabbit species that is similar to the lionhead rabbit) and Jacob’s sheep are only a few representatives of the manifold group of old domestic animals that are partly threatened with extinction. You can get to know them here in Warder. A large petting zoo offers children the possibility of immediate contacts with the animals. Visit the indoor zoo when it is raining. Special events, guided tours and births of animals make the visit of the Warder zoo a great experience throughout the year.
Special events like exhibitions, workshops, fairs and festivities on natural history and zoology take place in the zoo throughout the year.
favourable combined offer for groups (meals and admission charge)
Holiday apartments on the zoo premises, can be booked per week throughout the year
“Haus für Natur und Umwelt” (house of nature and environment) with changing exhibitions

Barbecue facilities

Guided tours, lectures and offers on individual topics (e.g. “from sheep to wool”, “around the farm”) are organised by the zoo school (responsible: Birgitt Fitschen, freelance biologist), charge: admission plus DM 50,- per guided tour
Public guided tours of the zoo on every last Sunday of a month at 11 o’ clock am
Publications on different zoological topics, especially concerning domestic animals, list on demand

The zoo is situated in the beautiful scenery of the Westensee national park with a number of walks, other recreational activities, riding facilities as well as Schloß Emkendorf (Emkendorf manorhouse) where events of the Schleswig-Holstein Musik Festival take place
The Baltic Sea at a distance of about 35 kms
400 m to the Brahmsee (Brahm Lake) with pedal boat rental

The “Haustier-Schutzpark Warder” (Warder protective zoo for domestic animals) is the first zoo in Germany that aims to preserve old domestic animals that are threatened by extinction. It offers the greatest variety in farm productive animals in Europe. The private institution is supported by the registered association “Tierpark Warder Förderverein e.V.”

Adults 12,- €
Children 9,- € 
Families 36,- €
Park for sustainable animal protection

The Arche Warder centre for rare and endangered breeds of domestic animals is unique in Europe. It presents the history of domestic animals and their significance for humans and their development. All of the park’s animals, for example Mangalica pigs, mammoth donkeys, Belgian beard rabbits, and Jacob sheep, are endangered. Plenty to experience on over 40 hectares of park grounds.

The ‚artefact POWER-PARK’ in Glücksburg, the first EnergieErlebnisPark (energy adventure park) in Germany, invites visitors to approach energy with all senses: to race the sun, to experience how much power is in wind and water, how we can use energy more carefully and how the greenhouse effect works. There are more than 30 stations where energy can be experienced in an amusing way. But sometimes it is thought-provoking: what can I do at home, in school or at work to deal carefully and future-oriented with our planet and the chances of the next generations? This watt tour of a special kind, from the fossil age of coal to the age of solar energy, is an experience for the whole family. The centre, which got the European Solar Prize in 1998, comprises an international guest house, holiday flats, rooms for seminars and festivities, a nature experience area and more. It is run by the ‚artefact gGmbH für Globales Lernen und Lokales Handeln’ (Artefact gGmbH for global learning and local acting).
Consulting service for topics relating to energy
Seminar rooms for your events
Family festivities (birthdays, marriages etc.) for a maximum of 40 people in our guest house

Interactive energy park

Germany’s first interactive energy park invites guests to experience energy with all their senses: race against the sun, experience the power of wind and water and how we can use energy more carefully, and understand the greenhouse effect. Have fun with energy at over 30 interactive, and at times thought-provoking, stations.

The Arthur Boskamp Foundation M.1 was founded in 2003 in remembrance of the entrepreneur Arthur Boskamp (1919-2000) who also engaged artistically. Aim of the foundation is to support and convey contemporary art. In addition, the foundation administers the artistic estate of Arthur Boskamp and maintains the historical building which houses the exhibition rooms. Each year the Arthur Boskamp Foundation offers a different curator the opportunity to try him- or herself out at the Exhibition Hall M.1. This offer is unique within the German exhibition and museum scene. Additionally, the foundation annually awards two grants to young artists from Northern Germany.
The Exhibition Hall M.1 presents topical artistic positions from different branches of modern art, photography, sculpture, painting, video art and installation. The foundation team is available for guided tours. Accompanying the exhibitions the foundation organises a varied programm of events.
There is a coffeehouse within the premises. Visitors are welcome during the opening hours of the exhibitions and on days of events.
On sale in the  museum: publications, post cards, calendars, literature (see above)

Exhibitions from different branches

The Arthur Boskamp Foundation M.1 was founded in 2003 in memory of the artistically-inclined entrepreneur. The foundation manages his artistic legacy and preserves the historic building that houses the exhibition. The M.1 reflects the current artistic stances of various branches of contemporary art, photography, sculpture, painting, video art, and installations.

noteValue: The ‚Atrium’, the museum at the locks, is situated directly at the ‚new locks’, which were completed in 1914, at the northern end of the Kiel Canal. The construction, operation and importance of the most frequented artificial waterway for seagoing vessels are documented by illustrated charts, model ships, model landscapes, working models, technical objects, video films and historical exhibits.The locks and the international shipping traffic coming in and out of the locks can be viewed daily during daytime from two observation decks and a marked loop trail. Visit of a historical gate carriage engine house and a Schütz engine cell is possible within guided tours.Entrance: Wasser- und Schifffahrtsamt Brunsbüttel (Brunsbüttel Waterways and Shipping Office), North porter, Gustav-Meyer-Platz 2

Guided tours:
Every 1st sunday of a month, 45-60 minutes.
March 17th – Nov. 3rd daily 10.30 am – 5 pm
Operator: Volkshochschule Brunsbüttel e.V.

Family ticket 6,- €
Guided tours by appointment
Museum at the lock

The exhibition in the ATRIUM uses information panels, model ships, landscape and working models, technical objects, videos, and historical exhibits to demonstrate the construction, operation, and significance of the world’s busiest artificial waterway.

In the former engine shed in Aumühle (close to Hamburg) steam engines for the suburban traffic from Hamburg to Büchen were stationed. Today the ‘Verein Verkehrsamateure und Museumsbahn e.V.’ (registered association of the friends of public transport and the museum train) presents historical railway vehicles there. The same association runs a museum train in Schönberg north of Kiel.
On the site of the museum there is a narrow-gauge track system, which is in use at the weekends. An exhibition on the tramway of Hamburg is shown in the suburban railway 1624. A remarkable exhibit is the double-deck-trailer no. 56 from the former narrow-gauge railway Altrahlstedt-Volksdorf-Wohldorf.
take the suburban railway S 21 from Hamburg main station to Reinbek, continue with the regional train in the direction of Aumühle/Büchen
Sat-Sun 12 am-6 pm
Free admission except for special events
Railway museum

A narrow-gauge railway is located on the museum grounds and is in operation at weekends. In the 1624 suburban railway car, an exhibition on Hamburg’s tram is on display. One of the museum’s most notable exhibits is the double-decker second car No. 56 from the former Altrahlstedt-Volksdorf-Wohldorf narrow-gauge railway.

resource.title: Lokschuppen Aumühle, T 3 Lokomotive
resource.description: Zu den wichtigsten Exponaten des Museums zählt die preußische "T3", jahrzehntelang die "Königin" der Neben- und Kleinbahnen sowie des leichten Rangierdienstes. Seit 2002, zu ihrem 100-jährigen "Geburtstag", ist die Lok als Leihgabe der "Freunde der Eisenbahn e. V." in Aumühle zu besichtigen.

name.label: Bad Oldesloe Museum of Local History and Culture

noteValue:
The local history museum owns an extensive collection on the pre- and early history of the Stormarn region. Among other things items of Paleolithic reindeer hunters and finds from the Mesolithic ‘Oldesloer Stufe’ as well as from the Brennermoor Neolithic settlement are exhibited. Archaeological finds from the Bronze Age to Early Modern Times like for instance Iron Age urns and tools, Slavonic potsherds and findings from the Limes Saxoniae are also presented.
In one section, which deals with the history of the town and with cultural history, products of a local pottery as well as tools and goblets of trade guilds are presented. Coins, documents and records of the history of the town, the saline and the spa supplement the presentation.
The museum shows changing special exhibitions, especially on topics concerning trade.
central location, close to the church
Parking facilities in the immediate neighbourhood
Workshop on the Stone Age with practical exercises (for school classes)
Guided tours on different subjects
Fri 2-4 pm, Sat 10 am - 12 pm and by appointment
Further information: local history museum Bad Oldesloe
Free
History of the Stormarn region

The museum of local history and culture has an extensive collection on the prehistory of the Stormarn region. In addition, the museum comprises a section on urban and cultural history. Changing special exhibitions with a focus on crafts are also on display.
Tue 2-6 pm and by appointment
Baking a hundred years ago

A complete bakery with 100-year-old equipment and a range of baking utensils are on display in the rooms of the former Friedrich Scharff bakery, including a flour mill from 1930, a roll divider from 1900, a kneading machine from 1920, and a flour sack from Cincinnati, Ohio.

In May 2008 the new Ostsee Info-Center (Baltic Sea Information Centre) in Eckernförde opened ist doors directly at the sea. 
Before entering the centre, one hardly anticipates the abundance of topics presented here. Three aquariums show the underwater world of the Baltic Sea from the shallow water zone to the deep water zone. The adventure tunnel offers a virtual walk over the ground of Eckernförde Bay. A landscape model demonstrates cliff line, salt marsh and beach. At the „wall of senses“ you can hear, see and feel marine characteristics. In the restored bridge of the fishing vessel „Klara“ you can experience a simulated fishing tour on the bay of Eckernförde.
The main attraction of the Ostsee Info-Center is a touch pool. It is designed in such a way that it allows the marine animals that live in there to retreat whenever they want. In addition to watch there is first of all the possibility to touch and feel the plants and animals that live in the pool. The touch pool area is always attended by a skilled emloyee.
Microscopes and binoculars are available for your own scientific investigations. Exciting movie screenings complete the offer. A roof-deck with small botanical garden gives you the possibility to experience Eckernförde Bay in reality and compare it with the virtual life presented in the centre.
Bistro
Shop

There are geological and ornithological walks for groups as well as for individual visitors. Dates and necessary information are provided by the Ostsee Info-Center.
In July and August the function room is changed into a children’s creativity area. A diversified and creative family program is offered there on weekdays.

Habitats of the Baltic Sea

Three aquariums display the underwater world of the Baltic Sea. A virtual tour takes visitors through a tunnel over the floor of the Eckernförde Bay. A model of the landscape shows the cliff line, salt marshes, and beaches. Visitors can take a simulated fishing tour on a restored ship's bridge. The Eckernförde Bay itself is visible from the rooftop patio, which also has a small botanical garden.

resource.title: Eingang des Ostsee Info-Centers nahe Strand und Hafen
Das spektakuläre Fühlbecken im Zentrum der Erlebnis-Ausstellung

noteValue: In 1970 there was an exhibition on the history and development of the town of Bargteheide. It formed the foundation of the local history and folklore collection. Enlarged by numerous donations from citizens a well-equipped museum developed, which is situated in the town centre directly on the B75. In addition to local records and items from the collection the museum shows how the people worked and lived in the region before mechanical production took the place of manual work. The main emphasis is put on the processing of flax. Records, tools, textiles, implements and furniture illustrate topics of local history and folklore. Furthermore the local pre- and early history is examined.
Sun 4-6 pm, weekdays by appointment
Free
Exhibition on the founding of the town

Located in the centre of the town, the museum grew out of a historical exhibition on the founding of the town. Archives and objects of local historical importance show how people in the region lived and worked before the transition from manual labour to mechanical production. The museum also features exhibitions on the history and folklore of the town and local prehistory.
Theatre, music, cabaret, cinema

Idyllically situated in the marshes of Wedel, the theatre ship hosts cultural events for every taste. The 100-year-old ship has had a colourful history replete with stories and anecdotes. It was purchased by its current owner, Hannes Grabau, almost 50 yea

The Lübeck art collection of the 19th and 20th century is located in two adjacent palatial merchants’ houses of the 18th century. The “Behnhaus” has the largest and most impressive hall in Lübeck and classicist wing rooms. It is regarded as the most beautiful merchant’s house in Northern Germany. The Drägerhaus presents the only preserved sequence of festivity rooms of the 18th century in Lübeck. Works by Johann Friedrich Overbeck and Gotthardt Kuehl constitute the foci of the collection of paintings. In addition, romantic paintings are presented, e.g by Caspar David Friedrich, Carl Blechen and Carl Gustav Carus. Works by Max Liebermann, Max Slevogt, Lovis Corinth and Edvard Munch are also shown. The Classical Modern collection includes works by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Max Pechstein and Ernst Beckmann. Contemporary art is represented by e.g. Schumacher, Dahmen, Neumann, Knaupp, Armando and Hoehme. Added are examples of realistic sculptures of the 20th century. In addition to the collection on fine arts, the museum shows home décors of the time around 1800 and the Biedermeier period (1815-1848). Arts and crafts of the 19th and 20th century are also exhibited. The Art Noveau section is worth seeing.

Jan.-March. Tue-Sun 11 am – 5 pm
April-Dec. Tue-Sun 10 am – 5 pm

19th century | Classical modern era

The museum is housed in two 18th century city palaces: Behnhaus and Drägerhaus. The interplay of the historical rooms and the gallery of 19th century and classical modern paintings has given the building the reputation of being one of the most beautiful museums in Northern Germany.

The New Botanical Garden of the Christian-Albrechts-Universität extends for eight hectares. It offers a comprehensive insight into the fascinating world of plants to academics, students and the public alike. Plants from all climate zones of the world bloom in the open air and the largest greenhouse building open to the public in Schleswig-Holstein. On a walk through a North American wood and past Mediterranean vegetation sections, heath, dunes, an alder fold, and an alpine rock garden the visitor reaches a Chinese coppice. He can stop at information boards along the walk. Cacti and succulents grow; orchids blossom and tropical flowers smell in the greenhouses. Visitors can discover where pepper grows and see how coffee, cacao or tea look like.
The garden, which is structured ecologically and geographically, also regularly offers changing exhibitions.
Every year on the 1st Sunday of June there is an open day. In the summer changing art exhibitions. Detailed information on many plant species.

Travel by public busses to the bus stop “Botanischer Garten”, there are also parking facilities for private busses, parking facilities for cars in “Ohlshausenstraße” (then walk along Leibnizstraße up to the end) and at the weekends directly on Leibnizstraße in front of the Institute of Biology

But it also offers a place of leisure and of delight at the flowers to all inhabitants or visitors of Kiel. After four predecessors on different sites in Kiel, it is now the largest botanical garden the town ever had. Additionally, it is the only scientific botanical garden in Schleswig-Holstein.

The admission is free except for great exhibitions. There is charge of DM 3,- per person for guided tours with at least 10 persons attending. Tours on many special topics or distinctive sections of the garden. Please call +49 (0)431-880 4276.

The new botanical gardens of Kiel University are eight hectares in size and offer scientists, students, and the public, in equal measure, extensive insights into the fascinating world of plants. Both outdoors and in the greenhouses, plants from all of the Earth’s climates display their beautiful flowers. Extensive information on many groups of plants.

The visitor finds the Brahmshaus in the centre of the town of Heide at the corner of the streets Lüttenheid and Neue Anlage. It cannot be missed with its whitewashed walls, its steep-sloped roof, its large window front and the roses in bloom. Under the pointed gable at the front there is a plaque with a reference to the Brahms family, who owned the house from 1819 to 1887.
In 1987 the ‚Brahms-Gesellschaft Schleswig-Holstein’ (Brahms Association Schleswig-Holstein) was founded. It wants to keep the memory of the great composer in Heide because the ancestors of Johannes Brahms lived in the town. The Brahms-Gesellschaft bought the house in 1988 and started alterations one year later. In 1990 the house was opened to the public. It has turned into a place of great cultural attraction in a short time.

April, May, October: Tue, Thu and Fri 2.30-4.30 pm, Sat 10.30 am – 12.30 pm or by telephonic appointment

Concerts | Exhibitions

Ancestral home of the composer Johannes Brahms. This lovely house is located near the Klaus Groth Museum on Lüttenheid’s museum island and hosts private concerts, small exhibitions, readings, and lectures.

The ‘Brahms Institute an der Musikhochschule Lübeck“ (Brahms Institute at Lübeck College of Music) was founded in 1990 with the purchase of the world-wide largest private Brahms collection of Kurt and Renate Hofmann. The institute is located in the Villa Eschenburg on the Jerusalemsberg in Lübeck since 2002. In addition to Johannes Brahms it also concentrates on Robert and Clara Schumann, Theodor Kirchner and Joseph Joachim. Furthermore it deals with interpreters and composers who were acquainted with Johannes Brahms as well but are almost forgotten today. These are: Theodor Avé-Lallemant, Richard Barth, Carl Georg Peter Grädener, Hermann Grädener, Richard Heuberger and Julius Spengel. Therefore the collection documents an important part of the German-Austrian history of music of the second half of the 19th century. The North German area with its centre in Hamburg is especially well represented.
Wed 2-6 pm, Sat 2-6 pm

The Brahms Institute is an international centre of excellence and documentation. The classical Brahms villa on the Jerusalemsberg in Lübeck is the ideal venue for concerts, symposiums, theme evenings, and changing exhibitions aimed at an interested audience.

noteValue: The Brunsbüttel local history museum was established in the former town hall of the old town in 1990. The town historical collection from the former local history museum in the ‘Matthias-Boie-Haus’ was integrated into the exhibition. The eventful history of the town at the entrance of the Kiel Canal is presented by historical maps, plans, photos and other records. Handcraft and objects of daily use show the work and life of families  that lived in Brunsbüttel. Records on the works of personalities such as artists and poets, Cape Horn sailors, pilots, whalers, peat cutters etc. constitute other focal points of the exhibition.Special exhibitions on different topics are shown in irregular intervals.
The museum is situated in the old part of Brunsbüttel close to the Jakobus Church

The 'Buddenbrookhaus' is a literature museum in the middle of the historical part of Lübeck. A visit leads you into the world of the 'Buddenbrooks' and the Mann family. The museum was altered in 2000 and got the museum prize of the Council of Europe in 2001. In a modern and vivid way, it presents the life and work of the Mann family in the exhibition "The Manns – a family of writers". The exhibition "The Buddenbrooks - one of the most significant novels of the 20th century" traces the novel at the scene of its action. Exactly in the place where the Mann family inhabited the first floor, the visitor finds the scenery room and the dining room as representation of rooms mentioned in the "Buddenbrooks". Connected to these "novel-themed rooms", an exhibition on the development and significance of the novel is shown. It combines academic precision with a most vivid presentation. In addition to the permanent exhibitions the Buddenbrookhaus offers numerous special exhibitions and a rich programme of literary events.

The Waldmuseum (forest museum) is located in an observation tower on the Wulfsboom, which is a 69 m-high older moraine elevation of the Hohe Geest. The visitor can enjoy an extraordinarily beautiful panorama of large parts of Dithmarschen from this landmark of the region. The view stretches from the mouth of the Elbe to the lowest land spot of Germany, which lies in the Wilstermarsch. It may seem surprising that the Waldmuseum, which is the only one of its kind in the country, is situated in this scarcely wooded coastal area of all places. This special museum exists since 1968 and emerged from the local school’s work in the forest. Considering the past 130.000 years, the geological history, as well as the history of the forests in this local area, are presented. Associated are plantings, which visualise the history of the forests, and ice-age detritus along the wood trail. Considerable collections on the local animal and plant world were developed. These collections are enlarged continually. The items on exhibition are changed from time to time. In addition to the presentation of scientific topics specific to the forest the museum also conveys information on recent problems concerning nature and environmental protection.
On sale in the museum: post cards, posters, information folders, leaflets

The ‘Kapitän-Tadsen-Haus’ (Captain Tadsen's House) on Hallig Langeness is an originally preserved Hallig house. [There are several small islands in the North Sea off the Schleswig-Holstein coast called ‘Hallig’.] Its foundation stone was laid in 1741. Living room, parlour, cellar, pantry, kitchen, basement and stable can be visited. These rooms are furnished with items and tools from the 18th century. Most of these objects originally come from the house. The Captain’s house uniquely documents the life on a Hallig 250 years ago.

A new centre for arts has been established in Büdelsdorf. It began as a private initiative of the ACO Group. Now, it is continued as KiC gGmbH in cooperation with the town of Büdelsdorf. Its tried and tested structures were kept and consolidated. So the fourth edition of the “Nord Art” in the year 2000 was no longer limited to the ACO-carriage shed and the park of the ACO-group but expanded into the public rooms of the town. During the “Nord Art”, artists from Northern Germany and the countries along the Baltic Sea present their works. The main emphasis is on painting and sculpture.
The stage in front of the old furnace is used for experimental theatre performances, musicals, cinema shows and concerts.

noteValue: In association with nature conservation, youth work and tourism the ‘Naturzentrum Nordfriesland’ (Nordfriesland Nature Centre) developed in 1976 as an information and activity centre on natural history. It instructs about the most important North Frisian land forms in 13 exhibition rooms with four big showcases: geest, woods, heath, bog, inshore waters, mud flats and the ‘Halligen’ (small islands in the North Sea off Schleswig-Holstein). The centre offers slide shows, nature handicraft workshops, amber cutting, guided tours and walks through heath and woods, around bird reserves, through mud flats and across to the ‘Halligen’. There are special programmes for school classes and groups. The nature centre is an officially recognized national park information centre. Annually changing special exhibitions on natural history are shown, especially in the period from May to October.

noteValue: The cultural monument from the period of promoterism houses one of the most comprehensive collections on the festivity of Christmas. Starting with the Biedermeier period the development of Christmas decoration and the arrangement of the Christmas festivity in past decades are shown. On the ground floor visitors can marvel at five historically decorated Christmas trees and find information on, for instance, Christmas during wartime, the illumination of Christmas trees or the production of Christmas baubles. One focal point of the collection is the importance of the Erzgebirge region for the production of Christmas decoration. Angels, pyramids and ceiling lights are decorations that are nationally well-known and delight many more people than just collectors and insiders. To end your museum visit you might like to come into the historic museum shop which offers nostalgic Christmas decoration and numerous books on Christmas.
Please see the map with directions under "Pictures"

Christmas collection

One of the most extensive Christmas collections can be found in the rooms of this Gründerzeit cultural monument. Starting in the Biedermeier period, the museum presents the development of Christmas decorations, how Christmas was celebrated over the past decades, historical Christmas tree decorations, Christmas during wartime, Christmas tree lights, or the production of Christmas ornaments.

The ‘Kloster Cismar’ (Cismar Monastery) was founded by Benedictine monks from Lübeck more than 750 years ago. Of the former monastery’s buildings the choir stalls of the church and the fountain house, which originates from the 13th century, have been preserved. Notable also: the recently restored altar from about 1300. Other historical parts of the buildings were altered particularly in the reformation and baroque period. In the basement of the fountain house there is an exhibition on the history of the site. In one part of the monastery great special exhibitions of the ‘Stiftung Schleswig-Holsteinische Landesmuseen Schloß Gottorf’ are shown during the summer months.

noteValue:
The town gallery was opened in the ELBEFORUM, a community and conference centre in Brunsbüttel, in November 1992 with an exhibition on Joseph Beuys. The town gallery does not present its yet small collection permanently because as an arts museum it is still to be developed. Instead it continually shows changing exhibitions on Modern Art from the Classical Modern to the Contemporary Avant-Garde. The gallery started the arts project ‘LAND:ART der KunST’ in Dithmarschen in 1996.
Meanwhile the emerging town gallery is well-known regionally and nationally because of its exhibitions on, for instance, Käthe Kollwitz, Ernst Barlach, Wilhelm Freddie, Rainer Fetting, Emil Schumacher, KD Arlt, Andreas Böhm, Raffael Rheinsberg, Ingrid Weidig, HD Schrader and Hansjörg Voth. Each year numerous visitors come to Brunsbüttel to discover Modern Art.A manifold educational programme for the young and the old is offered. There are artist’s workshops and lectures as well as the programmes ‘Stadtgalerie für Kinder’ (town gallery for children) and ‘Reisen zur Kunst’ (journeys to art).
All rooms of the ELBEFORUM are accessible for wheelchairs because they are either on the ground floor or can be reached by a lift

The city museum is located in the oldest still preserved noble residence from the early 17th century in the middle of the old part of Kiel. The impressive masonry with the original preserved sandstone portal, the historical rooms and the vaulted cellar are worth seeing.
Changing exhibitions on the town and cultural history of the 19th and 20th century as well as on critical graphics and arts and crafts are shown on the three floors of the Warleberger Hof. The permanent exhibition on maritime history is housed in the maritime museum of Kiel.

resource.title: Papiertheater Polidor

noteValue: Embark on a journey through time. The technical wonders of the computer pioneers were complex worlds of relays, tubes, transistors or microchips - unusual, mysterious. They are testimonies to ingenuity and the art of engineering. The first large-scale computer systems were only accessible to a few experts, hidden away like treasure troves. Learn about the lives of these people, their dreams, worries and triumphs. The museum's exhibits, some of which are listed, represent the development of information technology from its beginnings to the year 2000. On 800 m² of exhibition space, you will wander through mechanical computing technology, past the first digital computing systems of a Konrad Zuse and their successors to the world of home and small computers. Miniaturisation and the explosion of performance are essential features of a development that changed our lives like few others. A 21st century scenography leads you through the ambience of a listed bunker: authentic - medial - fascinating.

The computer museum is located on the campus of the FH Kiel (Kiel University of Applied Sciences), Eichenbergskamp 8 in Kiel-Dietrichsdorf. Motorists follow the signs “Ostuferhafen”, later “Fachhochschule”. By public transport you can reach the museum either by busses No 11 and get out at the bus stop “Fachhochschule” or by the Schwentine ferry F3 and get out at the pier “Dietrichsdorfer Brücke”.

The four-storey tower shelter from the Second World War has since been converted into a modern museum. Approximately 360 exhibits from the past decades of computer history are on display, beginning with Zuse KG’s electromechanical relay computer Z11 from 1958, which is now listed as a historical object.

noteValue: Shipping museum

The Aabenraa Museum focuses on shipping during the 19th century, when the city was shaped by large sailing ships travelling the long-haul routes to South America, China, and Japan, and shipbuilding. Collections of ship portraits, model ships, sailing souvenirs, figureheads, ship cranes, navigation instruments, and on the Jebsen shipping company, women at sea, and shipping in Sønderjylland.

In its collection the museum presents the eventful history of the Danewerk ramparts from the Iron Age through the Viking period and the Middle Ages up to the present. The ramparts were built between 650 and 1200 AC on the isthmus between the Treene and the Schlei. They have undergone multiple enlargements to their overall length of 30 km. As late as in the wars of 1848 – 50 and 1864 they were used militarily and provided with entrenchments. The exhibition is continually updated and extended. The museum staff and the labelling are bilingual in German and Danish.
The Danewerk is the biggest ground monument of Northern Europe. The preserved segments are partly in the close vicinity to the museum. It is possible to walk on most of them.
The museum presents changing special exhibitions on archaeological, historic and cultural historic topics especially from June to September.
On sale in the museum: publications (see above), handcrafted jewellery and replica, postcards, stickers, bags etc.

Walking tours on the ramparts:
Only 20 km of the formerly 30 km long Danewerk are still intact. The museum is an ideal starting point for walking tours on and around the ramparts. Close to the museum there are the remains of a brick wall that was built by the Danish king Waldemar the Great in the 12th century.

Responsible body of the museum is the Sydslesvigsk Forening (SSF, Norderstraße 76, 24939 Flensburg, Tel.: +49 (0)4 61 - 14 40 80), since 1920 the cultural main association of the Danish minority in Südschleswig (south Schleswig) with presently over 16.000 members.

Archaeological park and museum

The museum shows the eventful history of the Danevirke’s ramparts from the Iron Age and the Viking Age through the Middle Ages and up to the present. The ramparts were built on the isthmus between Treene and Schlei between 650 and 1200 AD and repeatedly extended. Special exhibitions on archaeological, historical, and cultural topics.

The 'Detlefsen-Museum' in Glückstadt is located in the 'Brockdorff-Palais' (Brockdorff Palace). This building is significant for the town and cultural history because it originates from the time of the foundation of Glückstadt in the 17th century.
Sönnich F. Detlefsen laid the foundation for the rich stock of the museum collection as early as 1894. The aim is to present a comprehensive picture of the former everyday life and work of the inhabitants of the Elbmarschen. To this end home décor, folklore, trade and commerce, whaling and seafaring, farming, vegetable growing and the old Glückstadt town pharmacy are subjects of the exhibition. Furthermore the museum owns a collection of paintings and drawings, among them are some by Max Kahlke and Karl Leipold. Special exhibitions and events like lectures, readings and concerts supplement and enrich the presentation.

History of Glückstadt

The Brockdorff Palace is significant for the history and culture of Glückstadt because it is one of the few remaining buildings from the 17th century, when the city was founded. Armaments, canons, uniforms, and flags testify to the city’s troubled history under Danish rule. The section on seafaring tells the story of the Greenland travellers and their battles with whales.

noteValue: The former house of the district judge was only recently restored along with the old post office and the house of the district reeve. It is situated in a charming park. Schwarzenbek belongs to the Lauenburg district. The knights’ family Wulf to Swarte Beke founded the village by building a castle. Once the village lay in the “jungle” between the Saxons and the Slavs. Today it is located on the important Hamburg-Berlin route in the “Sachsenwald” (Saxons wood). The Bismarck family owns this wood for the most part. They live close-by near Aumühle. Numerous special exhibitions mainly on arts and crafts, graphic arts and cultural history are presented in the former house of the district judge today. In addition, chamber concerts and other events take place there.
Fri, Sat, Sun 3-6 pm
Art exhibitions | Events
The district judge’s residence contains numerous special exhibitions, mostly on handicrafts, visual arts, and topics related to art history as well as other events such as chamber concerts.

name.label: District Museum of the Duchy of Lauenburg

noteValue: The former summer residence of the Mecklenburg dukes was built from 1764 to 1766. Since 1973 it houses the “Kreismuseum Herzogtum Lauenburg” (duchy of Lauenburg district museum). Starting with a presentation of archaeological finds, the museum also covers the history of the “Herzogtum Lauenburg” (duchy of Lauenburg) and the controversial issue of the border between East and West Germany of the recent past. Eye-catchers are the lavishly furnished kitchen, a pharmacy from the 19th century, a “Biedermeier” room as well as a photo shop with a camera collection, studio and laboratory. Art objects of the 19th and 20th century that are connected with the district of the “Herzogtum Lauenburg” are presented in other rooms. The architectural highlight of the house is the large Rococo hall with stucco works by Johann Nepomuk Mez. The manor-house has two annexes. These were once used as a horse stable and a carriage shed. Today they add a charming atmosphere to an originally fitted shoemaker’s workshop, a historical cartwright’s shop, carriages and sleighs. There is also an informative presentation on textile production in former times.
Lectures, readings, piano nights and concerts take place throughout the year in the Rococo hall.
We offer guided tours for different age groups by prior appointment. Special topics and the demonstration of old tools can be arranged.
Tue-Sun 10 am – 1 pm / 2-5 pm

Summer residence | History

Since 1973, the former summer residence of the dukes of Mecklenburg, built 1764-66, has housed the District Museum of the Duchy of Lauenburg. The museum features prehistoric artefacts, exhibits on the history of the Duchy of Lauenburg, and a depiction of the problems created by border between East and West Germany in recent history.

In three interconnected houses visitors can learn a lot about the history of Dithmarschen from the Middle Ages up to the present. The old museum from 1896 presents models on dyke building and drainage as well as highlights from the times of the “Bauernrepublik” (farmer’s republic) Dithmarschen. In addition, there are exhibits on home décor, organizations and guilds as well as a large collection of children’s toys. The maritime section with its originals and models constitutes an especially important part. In the building of the former Meldorf “Gelehrtenschule” (scholars’ school) the visitors encounter everyday items from the past 100 years. Different shops, an iron foundry, a factory producing carved trim, a hairdresser’s, a doctor’s practice, a liqueur factory, a cinema and a pub give an understanding of the working world as well as of the organization of leisure time in the recent past.Changing exhibitions on topics of regional and cultural history are presented in a special exhibition room of the “Dithmarscher Landesmuseum”.
On sale in the museum: publications, post cards, stickers

The museum is dedicated to the history of Dithmarschen from the Middle Ages to the present: Models of diking and drainage systems, showpieces from the period of the Peasant’s Republic, everyday life, guilds and associations, and children’s toys. A special focus is on shipping, with original pieces and models.

Pharmacy and apothecary garden, trade, and shipping – presented in traditional exhibits, multimedia content, and a digital tour on a tablet computer. A complete historical country pharmacy, exhibits on cargo shipping in Ditmarschen – from peat boats to container ships – a shipping-themed café, and the diversity of trade over the past decades are all part of the authentic exhibitions.

History of diving

Located right on the Flensburg Firth, this is Schleswig-Holstein’s only diving museum. Visitors will discover interesting exhibits from professional and hobby divers as well as learning about the history of diving.

Storm described the Fingaholi like this: “A strange decoration, a misshapen and ghastly gruesome picture…”. The exhibition in the small museum presents information on Storm, Schwabstedt and the castle. The history and the significance of the village are explained.

The local history of Schwabstedt

The collection of local history artefacts includes objects from the Stone Age, e.g. hatchets, grindstones, and a largely intact fossilised stool. Visitors can also see mediaeval bricks from the castle chapel assembled in the shape of a monastery. Numerous photos explain aspects of local history. Short texts tell the stories of famous Schwabstedters, e.g. Theodor Storm.
