Fauna and flora | Geology

The museum displays animals, plants, fossils, and rocks from northern Schleswig-Holstein. Located in the Sauermannhaus on the museum hill, the exhibition explains the creation and importance of typical landscapes in the region, including the Baltic Sea.
Hiking trail with over 30 sculptures

noteValue:
On December 26th 1996 the first German Sea Life Centre opened at Timmendorfer Strand.The visitors follow the water cycle on their tour of the Centre. They experience the natural habitats in the Schleswig-Holstein stretches of water. They follow the streams and rivers, which feed the freshwater lakes and finally flow into the sea. Concerning the sea, the visitors first gets insight into coastal habitats like sandy beaches, harbours and cliff-lined coasts. They get to know the sea grass meadows of the Baltic and the North Sea coast. Finally as a highlight, they are led through the habitat of the open sea by an underwater tunnel.
In the shaping of the different areas like the freshwater landscape with a waterfall, the tunnel at the bottom of the ocean and the ball-shaped tanks in the sea grass meadow, modern Aquarium technology goes hand in hand with careful design.Our offer is completed by lectures and presentations that vividly convey valuable information on life under water.
The Sea Life Centre has ramps for wheelchairs. There are also lifts.
Guided group tours are offered by prior appointment.
Sea Life offers surprises and special conditions for children’s birthdays if booked in advance
Sea Life presents the exhibition „Hunted hunters – on human beings and sharks“ in cooperation with Greenpeace

Only during this season: special exhibition “Mysterious creatures” on the less explored world of the deep sea where giant calamari and other exciting “mythical creatures of the under water world” are at home
Daily 10 am – 6 pm, June-Aug. 10 am – 7 pm

Adults 15,95 €
Children (3-14) 12,95 €
Experience aquatic habitats

Tours follow the water cycle of water and natural aquatic habitats of Schleswig-Holstein. In the ocean section, visitors learn about the coastal habitats on sandy beaches, in the harbour, and coastal cliffs. The tour continues along the seagrass meadows of the Baltic and North Seas, concluding with an underwater tunnel to habitats in the open seas.

At the Friedrichskoog Seal Centre, you can observe the seals and grey seals living permanently at the centre up close on land and under water. The exhibition "Native Seals in the Wadden Sea World Heritage Site", which will open in 2023, invites you to interactively learn about the biology and adaptations of marine mammals, threats and current conservation concepts. The unique habitat of the Wadden Sea and the North Sea as far as Heligoland is presented here with its special features.

In the "Seal View", the rearing and rehabilitation work from finding a pup to releasing it back into the wild is vividly presented. A 23 metre long glass front provides a view into the pools of the seals living permanently at the station as well as the inaccessible breeding area. The Friedrichskoog Seal Sanctuary is the only authorised sanctuary for abandoned or sick seals in Schleswig Holstein in accordance with the international seal convention.

Information | Rearing | Research

The centre has three functions: Information, rearing, research. Visitors are given numerous opportunities to learn about domestic marine mammals, their biology, the hazards of the Wadden Sea habitats, and protective measures. During feeding times, lectures are held on seal biology and the tasks of the Seal Centre.
Historical ships

Three historical ships complement the exhibition at the shipping museum and are an authentic testimony to the history of seafaring. The buoy tender Bussard, the fireboat Kiel, and the rescue lifeboat Hindenburg all played different roles in keeping people
Cinema and theatre run by volunteers

The cinema team consists of volunteers of all ages from the region. Together, they organise all cinema operations in cooperation with schools, clubs, and associations. The theatre is also run by volunteers and presents a diverse programme from plays and p

noteValue: A forge museum is established in the old smith’s house and yard. In addition, tools for farming and crafts are exhibited on the site.

Smithy and agricultural tools

The building was mentioned as early as 1722 as a blacksmith’s house and farm. Today, the museum contains a full set of forging equipment and various agricultural tools. The gem of the museum is a functional fire pump from the year 1888 belonging to the Jevenstedt voluntary fire brigade.
Exhibition and Renaissance space

Sønderborg Castle was built at the mouth of Alssund about 800 years ago. It has witnessed many events in the history of Denmark. The exhibitions cover the past 200 years of Danish history seen from the Southern Jutland perspective. Discover the 16th century princely chambers, including the Banqueting Hall and Queen Dorothea’s Chapel, the oldest remaining Renaissance space in the Nordic region.
Art exhibitions

The Sparkassenstiftung Schleswig-Holstein foundation boasts one of the largest, regional collections of contemporary art from a single state in Northern Germany. The foundation presents contemporary art with this collection and many special exhibitions.

The “Kunsthalle St. Annen” (St. Annen art museum) with a bistro and a museum shop was recently erected on the site of the former St. Annen convent church, which was built between 1502 and 1515. This building is a gift of the Possehl Stiftung (Possehl Foundation) in Lübeck to the old Hansa town of Lübeck. This new “Kunsthalle”, which is situated in the middle of the medieval Aegiedien quarter, is a unique place to encounter contemporary art and art of the 20th century.
Here the collections of the “Museum für Kunst und Kulturgeschichte“ (museum on art and cultural history) are presented.In addition, the Kunsthalle, which has excellent modern equipment, offers the possibility to show changing exhibitions of different kinds.

This new art gallery on the grounds of the church of the St Anne’s Priory in the centre of the mediaeval Aegidien quarter is a distinctive location for experiencing contemporary and 20th century art. noteValue: The museum is located in a former Augustinian convent from the early 16th century. It houses the most important collection of medieval carved altars in Germany. Among them is an outstanding Passion altar by Hans Memling from 1491. Panels and sculptures from the 14th to the 16th century supplement the section of religious art. The section on home décor is on the upper floor. Rooms furnished in the style of different epochs show how the citizens of the Hanseatic town lived from medieval times up to 1800. Exquisite furniture, splendid glassware, silverware, chinaware and faïence give evidence of the wealth and taste of inhabitants of the „Queen of the Hansa“. In addition, there is a toy section.

Mediaeval church art

The priory was built in the 16th century as a residence for the unmarried daughters of wealthy Lübeck merchants. Today, the harmonious combination of buildings and exhibits, Late Gothic monastery architecture and sacral art captivate visitors. Mediaeval church art in Lübeck is also on display.

Museum church | Exhibitions

The western facade of the church is a masterpiece of Gothic architecture with alternating glazed and unglazed bricks and a meticulous pediment design. Today, the aediculae are decorated with figures from Ernst Barlach and Gerhard Marcks. The inventory includes numerous artworks, murals, epitaphs, and Tintorreto’s Awakening of Lazarus. There are also changing exhibitions.

The “Petrikirche” (St. Petri Church) is one of the large medieval brick churches of the Hanseatic town. Its appearance as a spacious hall with five naves goes back to the 14th/15th century. In 1942 it burnt down completely. The extensive restoration was concluded with the renovation of the interior in the 1980ies. Almost empty, whitewashed and characterised by a distinctly cool atmosphere, the room with its pillars and vaults presents a spacious setting not only for services but also for the presentation of contemporary art since then. In this field the Petrikirche has become a forum that is internationally well-known for its spectacular exhibitions, installations or events.
Exhibitions | Music | Performance

The building was extensively renovated after a fire. Today, the spartan, whitewashed church has a calming effect with its numerous columns and vaults. No longer used exclusively for church services, it is an impressive setting for exhibiting contemporary art. The spectacular exhibitions, installations, and projects hosted in St. Peter’s Church attract attention from an international audience.

noteValue: Exhibition dedicated to textiles

The Stapelholm Huus displays exhibits devoted to textiles. A loom illustrates this old craft, which was once common in Stapelholm. One of the highlights of the exhibition is the festive clothing from the 19th century, including a linsey-woolsey skirt, silk apron, blouse, and bonnet. The museum also features old pieces of linen, chests, furniture, and other furnishings.
Theatre | Events

Founded in 1961, the statt-Theater Neumünster has been in the old Köstersch leather factory in Neumünster since 1989. The rooms were completely redesigned on the inside while the building was preserved in its original state on the outside.* In addition to presenting its own plays, the statt-Theatre also hosts comedy, cabaret, and theatre events for the Kulturfabrik Neumünster.

With the motto ‚experiencing natural and cultural history to preserve it for the future’ the AÖZA aims at reconstructing Neolithic cultivated land. On a site south of Albersdorf, which is very interesting in archaeological as well as environmental respect, a wooded open-air exhibition ground of approx. 40 hectare is created.
In this attractive refreshing area there are eight well-preserved megalithic tombs and ‘Langbetten’ (long burial mounds with stone edgings), which were erected along the west coast in the times of the first farmers and livestock breeders. The tombs, which are more than 5000 years old, are easily accessible on well-developed trails. A special attraction is the newly-built Stone Age settlement. It consists of Neolithic houses, which are reconstructed in original size. An exhibition in the ‚Bürgerhaus’ of Albersdorf (Oesterstraße) informs about the project and its scientific background.

Dithmarschen Stone Age Park is an archaeological open-air museum with a life-sized historical reconstruction. The approx. 40-hectare outdoor property shows how the first farmers in Northern Germany cultivated the land 5,000 years ago. The “Steinzeithaus” museum shows original finds from over 100,000 years of human history.

The museum is located in the historical farmhouse "Am Thie" since 1978. The Huguenot Duvier erected it as a village forge in 1750. With its extensive interior furnishing it offers manifold insights into rural life as it was before the coming of industrial times in Stormarn.The collections of traditional tools from farming, household and trade make up the centre of the presentation.
A rural spice and medicinal herb garden, chemist’s and veterinary’s tools and apiculture with a living bee colony, which can be watched in a show case, complete this section.
In the museum the visitor also finds the Hermann Claudius study and an archaeological study collection. In an adjacent building there is a bakery ready for use.
By car: motorway-exit Ahrensburg, carry on in the direction of Siek/Hoisdorf
By train and bus: underground No 1 to Großhansdorf, then bus No 369 to Hoisdorf

Museum of local history and culture

Since 1978, the museum has been housed in the historical farmhouse “Am Thie”, which was built by the Hugenot Duvier as a village smithy in 1750. Its extensive inventory offers a diverse look at village life in Stormarn prior to the beginning of the technological era.
Cinema

The Studio Filmtheater at Dreiecksplatz is the oldest continuously operated cinema in Kiel. Three of the four screens are still in operation. The fourth was converted into a café when the new studio was opened.

In the Frisian island house built in 1759 a regional history collection is shown. The Sylt chronicler Hansen established it. A section on pre- and early history supplemented by geological finds documents the development and the colonization of the North Sea island. Tombstones and stone coffins in front of the museum point out ancient burial rites. Traditional Costume, silver jewellery, furniture and farming tools show Frisian culture. Model ships, ship paintings and whaling tools present the history of seafaring. Works of important artists of the island like Dirks or Feddersen are exhibited. In the section “important figures of Sylt” the emphasis is put on the constitution-fighter and landvogt Uwe Jens Lornsen.

History of Sylt

The museum of local history and culture, whose collection was compiled by Sylt’s chronicler Hansen, is housed in a Frisian island house built in 1759. A prehistory section, stone graves and coffins, Frisian culture with traditional costumes and silver jewellery, furniture, farming tools, and the history of seafaring.

The four-masted barque „Passat”, which is one of the most beautiful sailing ships of the country, is anchored in Travemünde, Lübecks harbour on the Baltic Sea. The Hanseatic town of Lübeck rescued the ship from being broken up in 1959, gave it a permanent berth at the mouth of the Trave and put it under protection as an historic monument. Today the 56m-high masts of the ship are an emblem of Travemünde.
On-board exhibition

Travemünde, Lübeck’s harbour on the Baltic Sea, is home to one of the state’s loveliest sailing ships, the four-masted barque Passat. The Hanseatic city of Lübeck saved the ship from scrapping in 1959, gave it a permanent berth in Travemünde, and listed it as a historic monument. Today, the 56-metre masts are one of Travemünde’s landmarks.

noteValue: Concerts under a star tent

In the summer, free concerts from a range of genres are presented here. The “concerts under a star tent” have become a household name throughout the Segeberg region and beyond. It is impossible to imagine the local cultural landscape without them.

The „Haus Peters“ includes a former grocer’s shop from 1820. This shop makes the museum a very special one because it is still used as a sales room for numerous items. There are also a gallery and changing exhibitions. The “Horst Janssen Zimmer” (Horst Janssen room) in the gable with the “Eiderland-Mappe” (Eiderland folder) and the “Janssenhof” (Janssen farm) as well as the farmer’s garden with its herbaceous perennial plants and its summer flowers are well worth seeing. In the other rooms of the house there are special exhibitions on contemporary art and cultural history.
The historical grocer’s shop with its well restored fittings is probably the oldest rural shop of this kind in Schleswig-Holstein that is still preserved in its original place. The house of the Peters family was built around 1760. Between 1850 and 1955 it was the living section of a former so-called “Haubarg” (from “Heu Bergen” = gather in hay; special type of large farm building). It represents an important historical monument in cultural history that illustrates rural life in the 18th and 19th century. In addition to the original Biedermeier fittings of the grocer’s shop there is a good deal of “Gründerzeit” furniture in the kitchen and living rooms as well. It also derives from the former owners of the house. The visitor has the rare opportunity to experience living and working in the vicinity of the village and its surroundings, which once provided the grocer’s shop with its customers.

On sale in the shop: Bunzlau ceramics, glass, jewellery, linen products from Schleswig-Holstein and Lithuania, “Einbecker Blaudruck” (textile items with blue printed ornaments), books, graphics, posters, tea, homemade jam
open from 11 am to 6 pm throughout the main holidays (beginning of July until middle of September) as well as during the Christmas week. Closed on mondays.

Colonial goods shop | Exhibitions

The Peters’ Home is a very special museum with a historical colonial goods shop from 1820, a gallery, and changing exhibitions. The Horst Janssen room, located in the garret, deserves special attention as it contains the artist’s “Eiderland-Mappe” and “Janssenhof”. The cottage garden, and the special exhibitions on contemporary art and cultural history are also well worth a visit.

The historical steam ship “Alexandra” originates from the year 1908 and is the oldest of its kind that is still used for outings in public transport. A traditional club fondly maintains it. It anchors in the museum port and is available for regular round trips on the Flensburger Förde (Flensburg Bay) in the summer months.
The “Alex” used to transport millions of passengers preferably on the route Flensburg-Glücksburg until the shipowners took it out of service in 1975. At that time she was endangered of being scrapped. Only by the commitment of dedicated friends the “Alex” was commissioned again. In 1982 she was acknowledged as a cultural monument and in 1990 reclassified as a passenger ship.
Regular trips throughout the season
Historical boat rides

The historical steamer Alexandra was built in 1908 and is the oldest of its kind still used for outings on the Flensburg Firth. It was thanks to the efforts of dedicated fans that this ship was recommissioned. In 1982, it was recognised as a cultural monument and regained its classification as a passenger ship in 1990.
Lübeck’s oldest independent theatre

The theatre is located in a former free church built in 1905. It has 116 seats; enough room for 50 visitors. Self-written plays and impro theatre take visitors on a journey to entertaining worlds. Sometimes the show even starts in the foyer where the audi
Independent theatre since 1984

Theater Die Komödianten has been staging contemporary plays, comedies, and suspenseful and serious plays in an old metalworking shop in Kiel since 1984. During the summer, the theatre presents the wonderful fairy-tale The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint

The theatre at the Tremser Teich offers programmes for children and families almost year-round, including fairy-tales, adventure stories, and other plays. In addition, various educational theatre programmes are available, i.e. the popular Lübeck city adve
Theatre | Cinema

The theatre is next door to the Museum of Cloth + Technology and has 570 seats. The programme comprises plays, musicals, concerts, ballet, cabaret (“Kultur mit Biss”), and cinema (KINOBühne). Special events are aimed at children and teens. Schools receive free tours behind the scenes.

noteValue: Theodor Mommsen (1817 - 1903) received the Nobel Prize for Literature as the first German in 1902 for his extensive and still fundamental publications on Roman history and Roman constitutional law. Mommsen, who was a professor of law and a historian, came from the little village of Garding, which is located on the Eiderstedt Peninsula. A memorial with a small exhibition on the life and works of the scholar was established next to his birth house in 1987.
Please call by interest.
Free
Exhibition on the Nobel prize winner

In 1902, Theodor Mommsen (1817 – 1903) was the first German to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature for his comprehensive publications on Roman history and constitutional law, which are still important works today. A small exhibition on the scholar’s life and work was set up next to his birthplace in Garding.

The ‚Theodor-Storm-Gesellschaft“ (Theodor Storm association) runs a museum in the Storm house in the street ‚Wasserreihe’. The poet lived here from 1866 to 1880. The museum is fitted with original furniture and pictures from Storm’s possessions. The way the ‘poetic realist” Storm saw himself as a writer becomes obvious in a comparison of his poetry and reality. Among the twelve rooms of the house the “Poetenstübchen” (poet’s chamber) is most remarkable because Storm invented it for himself. It conveys an impression of the atmosphere Storm needed for writing. Here more than 20 novellas came to life, for instance “Pole Poppenspäler”, “Carsten Curator”, “Aquis submersus” and “Viola tricolor”.
Changing exhibitions give an insight into special problems of Storms writings and of his biography.
On sale in the museum: different publications (e.g. "Editionen aus dem Storm-Haus" – Storm house editions), postcards
Either by car or by train; parking facilities behind the town hall (5 minutes walking distance to the town centre)

The Theodor-Storm-Gesellschaft (Theodor Strom association) has tried to free Storm from the image of a regional writer since it was founded in 1948. It wants to establish an appropriate position of the poet from Husum within the literary history of the 19th century. The association aims at spreading the works of Storm, supporting the research on Storm as well as maintaining Storm memorials and Storm museums. The Theodor-Storm-Gesellschaft is one of the largest literary associations in Germany today. It has more than 1.400 members, among them many foreigners from more than 20 countries.
Since 1996 the Storm archive has some rooms of its own close to the Storm house. Academics and Storm enthusiasts find suitable facilities for their research there.

Adults 3,- €

Storm’s house | Poet’s parlour

The museum is located in the Storm house in the Wasserreihe, where Theodor Storm lived from 1866-1880. It contains the original furniture and pictures. Storm was a poetic realist and his literary self-image is revealed in the juxtaposition of poetry and reality. Of all the museum’s rooms, the “poet’s parlour” is a special treat as Storm designed it himself.

The “Erlebniswald” (adventure forest) Trappenkamp is the “educational forest centre” of Schleswig-Holstein and offers a special educational programme for nursery schools, schools, adult groups (information leaflets on request). The biggest North German open-air butterfly garden, the magical “Wichtelwald” (gnome wood), close-to-nature adventure trails, pure nature in the wild boar woods and many attractions from our calendar of events invite you to immediately investigate and experience the manifold native animal and plant world. Families with children will find a huge playground with barbecue facilities.

Educational forest centre

The Trappenkamp Forest Park demonstrates the diversity of domestic flora and fauna. It offers special educational programmes to groups at the largest open-air butterfly garden in Northern Germany, the magical gnome garden, adventuresome nature paths, accessible game reserves, an eagle arena, the TeamTower, and a large playground with several barbecues.
The exhibition shows tools for tree nurseries, which were needed for the production of coppices. Visitors can learn under which circumstances tree nurseries were run in former times.
Tue 6-8 pm, May-Oct. additionally Sun 2-6 pm and by appointment
free
Exhibition of tools
The exhibition showcases tools used by nurseries to grow trees and shrubs. Visitors can learn about the conditions under which nurseries were operated in the past.

name.label: U 995 Naval Memorial and Museum of Technology

noteValue:
The world-famous naval memorial of the Baltic seaside resort Laboe was built in the years 1927-1936. It is at the same time a memorial to people of all nations who died at sea and a memorial to peaceful shipping. The memorial has an 85 metre high tower, which visitors can climb up inside. It is situated close to the locks of Kiel Canal but on the opposite Eastern shore of the “Kieler Förde” (Kiel Firth).
There is an exhibition with model ships, maps, and dioramas on the history of merchant shipping and the navy in the “Historische Halle” (historical hall) at the Eastern side of the tower. The submarine U 995, which the visitors can enter, was put up on the beach immediately in front of the Laboe tower as a technical museum.

Preserved WWII submarine

U 995 is a Type VII C/41 submarine that was used by the German navy during the Second World War. It went into service in September 1943 and completed nine enemy missions. Since 13 March 1972, the submarine has been docked at the foot of the navy memorial and used as a museum ship.

The museum of the municipality at the ‘Bungsberg’ in Ostholstein is housed in the former village school from 1823. The local history collection of the village school was the foundation of the exhibition at the beginning of the 1960ies. Pupils, parents and teachers gathered tools and items from household, farming and local rural trades in the course of more than two decades. Under one single roof several working areas are presented, for instance a shoemaker’s workshop. In addition, the furnishings of the village school with old school benches, a school teacher’s desk, a blackboard, a calculating machine, illustrated wall charts and other objects once used in lessons are shown.
May 15th-Sept. 30th Tue, Fri 4-6 pm, July-Aug. additionally Sun 4-6 pm, groups by appointment

Rural trades | School

The museum is located in a fully-furnished former village school dating back to 1823. Its collection features local objects such as agricultural and domestic tools and rural trades from the region. Workplaces such as a shoemaker’s workshop are on display in the same building.

noteValue: In the former painter’s workshop samples, tools and records of this trade are presented. In addition, emergency bank notes, popular pictures, small household tools and historical photos of significance to local history are shown.

Former painter’s studio

The former painter’s studio features artistic work samples, tools, and documents as well as Notgeld (emergency money), popular pictures, domestic appliances, and historical photographs with considerable significance for the region’s history.
Farming and domestic tools from the rural working world, the equipment of a historic dental practice, a smith’s workshop and a bee house are presented.

Cultural assets from the village*

The collection comprises cultural assets from the village and farms. There is also a tradesman’s office, a historical hairdresser’s, a beekeeping museum, a historical smithy as well as a historicalm dentist’s office. A wide range of farming tools gives visitors an impression of life in the past. The Brodersby citizen’s initiative is also located in the museum.

The residential building, which houses the Dorfmuseum, is characteristic for Grube. It was built in 1890. Since 1993 it is the location for the folkloristic and archaeological collection, which was gathered by interested inhabitants of Grube and its surroundings.
Exhibited are, for instance, a completely furnished bedroom from around 1900 and a classroom of the 1930ies. Fishing, the cutting and use of reed as well as the draining of the lake in Grube in 1938 are documented by other items. Archaeological finds are also presented. A diorama on a scale of 1:10 shows the everyday life and the crafts of the Stone Age. Other fields or institutions that influenced the village of Grube are also dealt with: associations, rural trade, farming and the church.
A further attraction of the museum is a camera delivering still shots of the stork's nest in Grube to the visitors.
Guide on the museum, information sheets, post cards, photos

History of Grube

The village museum is located in a typical Grube house dating back to 1890. It houses a display of cultural and prehistoric artefacts collected by interested citizens. The displays and documentations include a fully-furnished bedroom dating back to 1900, a classroom from the 1930s, and information on fishing and reed processing.

The „Hohner Dorfmuseum“ (Hohn village museum) is located in a former cow-shed. The visitor finds a wide selection of tools for farming and housekeeping. Pictures and records inform about the history of the village.

Village history

The village museum in Hohn, located in a former cowshed, presents a large selection of agricultural and domestic tools. Photos and documents provide additional information about the history of the village.

The exhibits of the collection are presented in the attic of the Schacht-Audorf local administration. The visitor can see tools and objects that illustrate daily village life over the course of time. In addition, pictures explain the working routine on the fields, on the farm and in the house.
Volunteers work several hours a week in the museum and archive. We are happy to adapt the opening hours to your wishes by arrangement.
admission free
Village history

The exhibits are located in the top storey of the town hall. Tools and objects document how village life changed over time. In addition, photos illustrate work routines in the field, in the yard, and in the house.
A real-life village museum

Initially, a traditional village museum was planned, but gradually the idea evolved to turn the village into a real-life museum by incorporating local historical sites. While touring the village, visitors will find numerous marked sites and information boards. In the House of History, additional information, objects, photos, and short films go into more depth.
Socio-cultural centre

Since 1982, the former bathhouse has been the venue for concerts, readings, workshops, lectures, parties, and film screenings. The focus is on offering a cultural programme for a wide range of subcultures.

The 'Naturschutzgesellschaft Schutzstation Wattenmeer e.V.' is a private, non-profit-making nature conservancy organisation, which was founded in 1962. Its aim is to further understanding of and fascination for the 'mud flat ecosystem' and the North Sea. In this way it wants to enhance the protection of these biospheres and also the willingness to protect them.
Wadden Sea ecosystem

The Wadden Sea Conversation Station organisation is aimed at increasing general knowledge about and interest in the Wadden Sea ecosystem and the North Sea, thus promoting the willingness to protect these habitats.

noteValue: The main emphasis is put on a picture chronicle of Wanderup village and on exhibits that illustrate the rural working world. Farming tools are shown in the barn, which was re-erected in this place.

Photo chronicle of Wanderup
The museum is dedicated to a photo chronicle of the village of Wanderup and exhibits on rural labour. Agricultural equipment is on display in the potato steaming barn.
Wedel’s memory

The city archives promote research and education and serve as a basis for discussing history, culture, and politics in Wedel. They comprise documents form Wedel, Schulau, and Spitzerdorf from 1602 onwards and a large collection of pictures, newspapers, ma

The Wedel collection on its town history covers the period from the first mentioning in a document in 1212 up to the 1950ies. Different topics and fields are presented: for instance women’s work in farming, dairy farming and housekeeping or traditional trades of the Elbmarsch region like that of the “Bandreißer” and the ropemaker. The National Socialist period in Wedel is presented in its effect on daily life. 70% of the town was destroyed by bombs in 1943. In the post-war era today’s museum building also served as an emergency accommodation. The history tour ends with the 1950s, with the presentation of the economical reconstruction and the social house building.

Wedel between 1212 and 1950

The collection on the history of Wedel comprises the period from the first mention of the city in 1212 to the 1950s. The museum presents various topics and areas: The work of women in agriculture, dairy and domestic work, typical trades in Elbmarsch such as hooping and ropemaking, and the Nazi era.

In Itzehoe a new museum was established in 1995. It presents the work of the painter, architect, interior designer and designer Wenzel Hablik (1881-1934). The artist, who was born in Bohemia, is regarded as one of the most important representatives of the German architectural Expressionism. In more than twenty years of work Hablik developed an extensive concept for a visionary and utopian architecture, which he recorded in paintings and drawings. Thanks to a broad education and versatile approach, he also worked in fine and graphic arts and in all fields of applied art. He designed furniture, wallpaper patterns, cutlery, jewellery as well as complete interior furnishings for several private and company buildings. Hablik also became known as a designer of textiles.Library and archive on the architecture of Expressionism. Special exhibitions on the artist and associated fields, especially architecture and design.
On sale in the museum: publications (see above), post cards, reprints of etchings by Wenzel Hablik, high-quality replicas of jewellery

Creativity in Northern Germany

The painter, graphic artist, artisan, interior designer, and visionary Wenzel Hablik and his wife, the master weaver Elisabeth Lindemann, were active in Itzehoe in countless different ways. The Wenzel Hablik Museum provides an overview over the couple’s varied works.

noteValue:
Willy Brandt. A political life in the 20th century.

The Willy Brandt House Lübeck is the place for contemporary history in the birthplace of the first Social Democratic German Chancellor and later Nobel Peace Prize winner.

Whether as a young Social Democrat, Nazi opponent and political refugee, or later as a politician and statesman, Willy Brandt's lifelong commitment to democracy is still inspiring today. Like hardly anyone else, he changed the Federal Republic of Germany and stood up for peace and freedom in Europe and the world. The permanent exhibition is dedicated to this political life and offers a fascinating walk through the history of the 20th century. The multimedia and interactive permanent exhibition on Willy Brandt's political life and work invites visitors to critically examine history and the present.
The house has barrier - free access. Users of wheelchairs with a total weight over 150 kg will be assisted with changing into a lighter wheelchair.

By bus from the central station with bus numbers 1, 11, 21, 31 and 34, from the Stadthalle with bus numbers 4 and 32, getting off at bus stop “Katharineum” (50 m walk), and from the Burgtor with all numbers except number 10, stopping at “Koberg” (100 m).

If coming by car, it is best to park at the canal (follow traffic sign: Parkplätze Ost) and walk up Glockengiesserstrasse (500 m), since there is no possibility of parking directly at the house.

On Saturdays and Sundays at 3 p.m., the Willy Brandt House Lübeck invites visitors to free public guided tours of the permanent exhibition.
Further guided tours and mediation offers for groups and school classes at https://willy-brandt.de/ausstellungen/bildung-und-vermittlung/luebeck/

A political life.

The Willy Brandt House Lübeck is the place for contemporary history in the hometown of Germany’s first Social Democratic chancellor. Like no other, Willy Brandt changed the Federal Republic of Germany and dedicated himself to peace and freedom in Europe. The exhibition focuses on his political life, providing a fascinating tour through the history of the 20th century.

Fauna and flora

In the past, the warehouse was used to store goods for the old town hall built in 1585. Today, it houses the museum. With its half-timbering, crane, two-piece trap door, and the reinstated prison door, the warehouse is a dignified location for the three-storey permanent exhibition on the fauna and flora of the Wilster marsh.

name.label: zeiTTor – Museum of Neustadt in Holstein

noteValue:
You can discover many interesting and exciting items in the Neustadt museum for 100 years already: fossils, a very old logboat, ballad-monger picture sheets, originals from Neustadt and its surroundings and much, much more.

A special attraction is the unique collection of archaelogical finds from the well-known excavation site „Marienbad“ in Neustadt harbour. Some finds are singular within Northern Europe.

The museum is located in the „Kremper Tor“ (Krempe Gate) and its outbuildings. This gate belonged to the medieval fortification of the city. Except from Lübeck it is the only preserved city gate in Holstein.

The museum offers educational hands-on activities as well as, for instance, humorous guided tours on different topics. The events focus on touching and trying out genuine exhibits.
Every Saturday the experimental archaeologist Manfred Pfeifer shows you how to work bone.
If you find fossils or Stone Age tools on the beach you can have them identified in our Archaeological consultation hour on Fridays between 3 and 5 pm.

The zeiTTor shows how people lived both 7000 and 50 years ago. Each room contains activity areas or authentic “points of contact”. The museum focuses on people and their environment during the Stone Age and life in Neustadt in the past. The archaeological artefacts from the Marienbad, a settlement on the floor of the Baltic Sea dating back to the Mesolithic Age, are especially well known.

noteValue:
The zoological museum is one of the twelve exhibition facilities of Kiel University. It was designed by the architects Martin Gropius and Prof. Karl Möbius from Berlin as Zoological Institute and Museum. Today the building is a modern daylight museum. In a large hall the exhibition "From the whale to single-celled organisms" is presented. In its centre the skeleton of a not fully-grown blue whale is exhibited. A study exhibition shows European birds, which are arranged according to the scientific order. On the ground floor two changing exhibitions per year present ecological interrelations of a symbiosis or, if possible, results of recent research.
Collections: samples of different expeditions (e.g. "First plankton expedition 1889"), tropical bird skins of the "round-the-world-sailing-tour of the Galathea" from 1845-1849, collections of insects and molluscs – among them several butterfly collections from Schleswig-Holstein – as well as scientific comparative collections of beetles, dipterans and sawflies.
An example of an extinct great auk and a complete skeleton of an also extinct solitaire (dodo-like bird species) belong to the zoological treasures.
Förde steam boat: “Seegarten” landing stage

The Kiel Zoological Museum is a university institute and the junction between research, teaching, and the public. The exhibitions present modern findings from marine research, zoology, and evolution based on historical collections. The focus is on the museum’s valuable original prepared specimens. Showcasing the fascinating objects is just as important as providing information.
